												I wouldn't consider this a simulator if I was at gunpoint.  The flight mechanics are... rough to say the least.  The keyboard mapping is almost absent from what I can tell.  Flying by mouse, there are maybe five or so keys including a second primary fire button... just in case your left click breaks.  Taking off from a carrier I found myself rocketed abruptly upwards by some mystical force halfway across the deck and then when landing stopped about as abruptly as hitting a brick wall.  The voice acting in the campaign felt a bit forced and was empty of depth or feeling (especially in the Japanese campaign) and didn't really contribute anything to a storyline.  The missions are extremely repetetive as well (bomb a target, switch planes, bomb said target again).On the better side, the game did have some pretty cool explosions and the planes burning out of the sky were as asthetically pleasing as it gets.  Bullet and cannon impacts in both soil and water are pretty well mimmicked although the auto aim defeats the whole purpose of WWII dogfighting.  Ships will sink if they are destroyed, which is nice, although I found it odd that the USS Arizona was capsized by torpedos and fully submerged in shallow water in about one full minute...All in all I'd say this game is worth 3 out of 10 stars.  Would not ever recommend this to anyone looking for a "flight sim" despite what any of the trailers or pictures make it out to be.

												No. Just no. Don't waste your money.I was interested in seeing how historically accurate this game was, but couldn't get past the poor gameplay. According to other reviewers, it wasn't much. From the little bit I've seen of the game, it had a fairly simplistic view of the war and Japan. Quite honestly, it felt like the gang from Team America: World Police had a hand in the writing. I'd be intested in seeing the Japanese campaign, but the gameplay was much too boring - sometimes frustrating to actually bring myself to unlock it.The keyboard controls are fairly simple. Hold Shift: go faster; Hold Ctrl: go slower until your engines cut out and you start to stall (good luck dropping torpedoes because you'll stall before you can go slow enough to drop them); Hold no keys: speed remains somewhere between stall speed and max speed; Hold Tab: Target cam (bonus points if you can spot the problem with this default); WASD: various camera angles.If you're like me, you'll get bored once you figure out these basics and you'll be sitting with your head propped up on your arm trying not to fall asleep while you line up a shot with a slow moving bomber.The game breaks a cardinal rule concerning the tutorial level. "The player cannot fail". If a player fails at any portion of the training level, he/she will have to play all the way through it again. At best, if a failure occurs, the game should commence from a checkpoint that's fairly close or the scenario should be designed in such a way that the player cannot fail easily. Instead, you can quite easily find yourself in a progression break where the only option is to suicide.This game is developed and designed like a budget title. I'd say this game is worth maybe a couple bucks. Don't buy it if it's any higher than that.

												I have played Air Conflicts: Secret Wars and I have this game too, but somehow I just can't get into this game. Basically, this simulates the Pacific Carrier Wars between US Navy and Imperial Japanese Navy of WW2, where you pilot planes from either side on various missions featuring rather arcadish controls. Graphics are actually quite good, with multiple views: cockpit, follow-cam, or forward-no-cockpit. For planes with rear gunner, you can go there too. Planes suffer realistic damage when hit. Flak will put holes and ragged edges to your control surfaces and wings, plane will start to smoke, and so on. Ground detail is also quite good, with all the terrain features very visible, and structures easily seen. Sound is decent. The game gives you a "play in a team" feel by giving you several AI squadron mates. However, they don't seem to do anything. Instead, you can switch to them (swap planes) and fly them when your plane ran out of bombs or whatever. Then when you jump back out that pilot will fly back to carrier to rearm and come back out. However, the controls are horrible. I don't think it's my gamepad... which is a Xbox360 wireless only a few months old. I can't seem to stablize the plane to do the bomb or torpedo runs. The plane just bounce left/right/left/right as if my controls are lagging. After prolonged play all the planes want to nosedive (lost calibration). This doesn't seem to affect dogfighting much as planes are always going all over the place, but for stable bombing this is impossible. Furthermore, there's no explanation on bombing or torpedoing. Nothing in the manual. Missions are extremely long, as you are supposed to experience very bit of the battle. Instead of 3 different versions of battle from 3 different POVs, you will play all three... First you launch as fighters to sweep the sky of enemy planes, and bomb a few AA sites. Then you go in as dive bombers and take out structures and fuel farm. Then you play as torpedo bombers and torpedo 2 cargo ships just off the island. When bombing and torpedoing aren't working, frustration sets in. Somehow I just can't enjoy this game.

Posted: October 19, 2014
												To start things off, I've always loved these fighter planes-esque games (e.g. War Thunder, Pearl Harbor). AC:PC was honestly the best game on my joystick that I've ever played (other than Star Wars: Rouge Squadron). Two separate campaigns in the WWII era, having the choice between Japanese and Americans were very interesting. Upon initializing the mission, you'll notice that every mission is taking off from an aircraft carrier (duh!). And unlike most single player campaign mode fighter games, you aren't the only one in the sky. You've got a whole squadron behind you (or in front, I'm always in the back) and the best part is that you can switch planes like how you switch players in FIFA. The pilots also have a ranking system e.g. Private, Captain and added skills to them depending on rank. It gets emotional when one of my starred pilots die in combat. The overall dogfighting is very fun and engaging, but when it comes down to missions, not so much.Yes, there's two campaign modes, but all the missions are very mundane; some just bore me to death, literally. These include trying to spot an enemy carrier that's off the coast for 3 minutes, attempting to dive bomb a radio tower because your fighter planes ran out of ammo, or trying to kill the rest of the enemy squadron with one plane left. Not to mention that the flak cannons on the ground do insane damage. Aim is quite hard with a joystick (you can play with a keyboard, but it still doesn't help the aim) and the bombs/torpedos take some skill to land unless you're literally right above the enemy unit. However, that still doesn't take away the fun of things.What I really enjoyed most was bombing ships. I love bombing runs; going down an entire stirp of an enemy aircraft carrier brings me so much joy. Knowing you have air superiority against this bomber always brings me to rejoice my lovely machine guns. Also, you can specialize the weapons on the plane to the mission, making even greater firepower.Overall, the game was very enjoyable. Missions were a pain, but atleast AC:PC got the basics down.

												Now this game is sort of hate-love relationship.I did play the game with a XBox 360 controller on simulation settingI did not play the multiplayer part.It does have two different control modes: Arcade and Simulation, both for Mouse/Keyboard and controller.Arcade is what the name suggests, easy controllable fast action.Simulation, on the contrary, is much harder and more realistic in terms of flight dynamics. For this mode some training (like the training mission) is advisable. But even when using simulation, the game is still more arcade than some other games, so if you're a hardcore simulation fan, you won't miss anything here.The missions are relatively straight-forward: Destroy that ship, destroy that many planes in XX minutes and so on.I lacks freedom, but if you don't mind that, the air-action is doing fine.There are however some boresome missions, like on the japanese campaign where you have to do some very precise bombing with limited number of planes (and bombs, that is). Here I needed several relaods of that single mission to make it in time.That being sad, the scripting is still buggy; and I don't expect it to be patched any more.In 2 levels the level border (you cannot fly too far away from the main objective) is set really stupid; I even had 2 occurences where I switched to another, previously AI-controlled plane, and instantly ended up in loosing the mission due to "leaving the battlefield"...Overall, 60% of the missions are really enjoyable, the rest ranges from "nice try" over "boresome" to "annoying".Also there is at least one real show-stopper bug:After finishing the last mission in the japanese campaign, the game crashed. And looking up in the game hub, it seems not to be an isolated problem--In general the game is not bad. It's entertainable for about 8-10 hours each campaign and there is a multiplayer part.But I suggest you buy this game only if you don't mind some bugs, a more or less arcade-like flying style and relatively straight-forward mission design.For myselfI don't think I wasted my time here, but if I'd payed more than 5€, I would be sort of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥due to the bugs and mission design flaws.

												I'm not a huge flight simulator guy, but this came in a bundle and I like to always branch out when I have the opportunity. Meh, if you've ever played a flight sim and realized that its only fun for a short while, well that's my recurring experience with the genre too. This game would be much more fun to me as a level in a full videogame (Like how GTA V has pretty detailed flight in their planes). Just the game alone doesn't have enough diversity for me, the idea that you are going to be doing the same exact specific thing throughout the entire campaign, makes it hard to enjoy.On an opposing note, there are different planes and different weapons and different enemy targets that do mix up the levels enough to make it bearable. The first couple levels are actually fun until you try to fire some torpedoes (Those things will always be a mystery to me), and if there was a bit stronger storyline, I might be able to get more into it. Text scrolls across the screen and shows you a map of pearl harbor and other islands. Actually as I'm writing this, I'm realizing how terrible this review will be. I mean its obviously targeted at people who are into flight sims and/or war games enough to read a review about one written by someone who has absolutely no interest in either. So how about this, don't trust me, unless you are here because you also dislike war plane games and for some reason want to give them yet another chance. I'd say if this game is free or under $2 then you'll probably enjoy it that much. Otherwise, it gets old pretty fast.The biggest problem with the game is the ever changing difficulty level. Rookie, the lowest casual level gets hard to the point where all of the backup planes with be blown up before you can even switch to them. Don't even get me started on the actual simulation mode (as opposed to controller arcade mode).  So to summarize this confused/confusing babbling: It keeps you somewhat entertained briefly and then get too difficult to be fun anymore. I beat the primary campaign and am leaving it at that.Note: Again, I am not into this genre so take this opinion lightly.Overall Score: 6.5/10 (The actual game play was done well)

												If you have a Controller, this game can be fun. I played it in Contoller-Arcade mode.Probably not worth the full price, but if you got this game from a pack, then you won't regret playing it.There is a decently long American and Japanese campaign where you get to patrol the skies, fight in historical battles and sink a lot of ships and even some large Historical Carriers.With each faction, you get three types of fighters: dog fighters, ground bombers and sea bombers.You control one plane at a time but can switch to the next pilot at any time. This is done to get you back into the fight without wasting time going back for ammunition.With each battle, your surviving pilots gain experience and maybe even a few perks. You can edit your roster between missions to train weaker pilots or to make sure you have good AI pilots by your side.If one of your planes goes down, there is still a chance that your pilot bailed out and survived. If you are not pleased with the outcome, you can always restart a mission or redo the last checkpoint.I personally like playing this game (with a controller) and some of the missions, though sometimes hard, are quite fun.I can't recommend you pay the full price for it or try to play it without a controller, but you won't regret owning this game.

												Now what is good about this arcade style world war 2 combat simulator. A pro in this game are the graphics. It is very well done. Firing the guns is amazingly realistic looking. The sensitivity in the controls makes aiming more of a burdon that it should be. I also tried flying with keyboard and mouse. That is a lot easier but not the way I want to play this kind of game. Also the lack of coop is a con in this game. Perhaps on some gaming fora there are some sollutions to this problem. It seems to me this game has some minor bugs still, but that doesn't mean it can't be fun.
